          • Vectorized (universal) functions
            • Characterizing arrays
              • max: Return the maximum along a given axis.
              • argmax: Return indices of the maximum values along the given axis.
              • min: Return the minimum along a given axis.
              • argmin: Return indices of the minimum values along the given axis of a.
              • ptp: Peak-to-peak (maximum - minimum) value along a given axis.
              • trace: Return the sum along diagonals of the array.
              • mean: Returns the average of the array elements along given axis.
              • var: Returns the variance of the array elements, along given axis.
              • std: Returns the standard deviation of the array elements along given axis.
              • all: Returns True if all elements evaluate to True.
              • any: Returns True if any of the elements of a evaluate to True.
            • Sums, products, differences within array
              • prod: Product of array elements over a given axis
              • sum: Sum of array elements over a given axis
              • nansum: Sum of array elements over a given axis treating NaNs as zero
              • cumprod: Cumulative product of elements along a given axis
              • cumsum: Cumulative sum of the elements along a given axis
              • diff: Calculate the n-th order discrete difference along given axis
              • ediff1d: Differences between consecutive elements of an array
              • gradient: Gradient of an N-dimensional array
              • trapz: Integrate along the given axis using the composite trapezoidal rule
              • convolve: Discrete, linear convolution of two one-dimensional sequences
              • interp: One-dimensional linear interpolation
            • Logarithms and exponentials
              • logaddexp: Logarithm of the sum of exponentiations of the inputs
              • logaddexp2: Logarithm of the sum of exponentiations of the inputs in base-2
              • power: First array elements raised to powers from second array, element-wise
              • power: First array elements raised to powers from second array, element-wise with automatic domain
              • exp: Calculate the exponential of all elements in the input array
              • exp2: Calculate 2𝑝2p for all 𝑝p in the input array
              • log: Natural logarithm, element-wise
              • log: Natural logarithm, element-wise with automatic domain
              • log2: Base-2 logarithm of 𝑥x
              • log2: Base-2 logarithm of 𝑥x with automatic domain
              • log10: Return the base 10 logarithm of the input array, element-wise
              • log10: Return the base 10 logarithm of the input array, element-wise with automatic domain
              • logn: Return the base 𝑛n logarithm of the input array, element-wise with automatic domain
              • expm1: Calculate exp(𝑥)−1exp⁡(x)−1 for all elements in the array
              • log1p: Calculate log(1+𝑥)log⁡(1+x) for all elements in the array
              • sqrt: Return the positive square-root of an array, element-wise
              • sqrt: Return the positive square-root of an array, element-wise with automatic domain
              • square: Return the element-wise square of the input
              • reciprocal: Return the reciprocal of the argument, element-wise
            • Trigonometric and hyperbolic functions
              • sin: Trigonometric sine, element-wise
              • cos: Cosine element-wise
              • tan: Compute tangent element-wise
              • arcsin: Trigonometric inverse sine, element-wise
              • arcsin: Trigonometric inverse sine, element-wise with automatic domain

              • hypot: Given the “legs” of a right triangle, return its hypotenuse
              • sinh: Hyperbolic sine, element-wise
              • cosh: Hyperbolic cosine, element-wise
              • tanh: Compute hyperbolic tangent element-wise

              • arccosh: Inverse hyperbolic cosine, element-wise

              • around: Evenly round to the given number of decimals
              • rint: Round elements of the array to the nearest integer
              • fix: Round to nearest integer towards zero

              • ceil: Ceiling of the input, element-wise
              • trunc: Truncated value of the input, element-wise

              • nan_to_num: Replace NaNs with zero and inf with finite numbers
              • real_if_close: Truncate complex parts if within `tol` times machine epsilon of zero
            • Float functions
              • isreal: Returns a bool array, where True if input element is real
              • iscomplex: Returns a bool array, where True if input element is complex
              • isfinite: Test element-wise for finiteness (not infinity and not NaN)
              • isinf: Test element-wise for positive or negative infinity
              • isnan: Test element-wise for NaN and return result as a boolean array
              • signbit: Returns element-wise True where signbit is set (less than zero)
              • copysign: Change the sign of 𝑥1x1 to that of 𝑥2x2, element-wise
              • nextafter: Return the next floating-point value after 𝑥1x1 towards 𝑥2x2, element-wise
              • modf: Return the fractional and integral parts of an array, element-wise
              • ldexp: Returns 𝑥12𝑥2x12x2, element-wise
              • frexp: Decompose the elements of 𝑥x into mantissa and twos exponent
              • fmod: Return the element-wise remainder of division
              • floor: Return the floor of the input, element-wise
              • ceil: Return the ceiling of the input, element-wise
              • trunc: Return the truncated value of the input, element-wise
            • Bit-twiddling functions
              • bitwise_and: Compute the bit-wise AND of two arrays element-wise
              • bitwise_or: Compute the bit-wise OR of two arrays element-wise
              • bitwise_xor: Compute the bit-wise XOR of two arrays element-wise

              • mod: Return element-wise remainder of integer division

              • tensordot: Tensor dot product over given pairs of axes

                  • Bessel Functions
                    • Bessel Functions
                      • jv: Bessel function of the first kind of real order 𝑣v, 𝐽𝑣(𝑧)Jv(z)
                      • jve: Exponentially scaled Bessel function of the first kind of order 𝑣v, 𝐽𝑣(𝑧)𝑒−|ℑ𝑧|Jv(z)e−|ℑz|
                      • yn: Bessel function of the second kind of integer order 𝑛n, 𝑌𝑛(𝑥)Yn(x)
                      • yv: Bessel function of the second kind of real order 𝑣v, 𝑌𝑣(𝑧)Yv(z)
                      • yve: Exponentially scaled Bessel function of the second kind of real order, 𝑌𝑣(𝑧)𝑒−|ℑ𝑧|Yv(z)e−|ℑz|
                      • kn: Modified Bessel function of the second kind of integer order 𝑛n, 𝐾𝑛(𝑥)Kn(x)
                      • kv: Modified Bessel function of the second kind of real order 𝑣v, 𝐾𝑣(𝑧)Kv(z)
                      • kve: Exponentially scaled modified Bessel function of the second kind, 𝐾𝑣(𝑧)𝑒𝑧Kv(z)ez
                      • iv: Modified Bessel function of the first kind of real order 𝑣v, 𝐼𝑣(𝑧)Iv(z)
                      • ive: Exponentially scaled modified Bessel function of the first kind of real order 𝑣v, 𝐼𝑣(𝑧)𝑒−|ℜ𝑧|Iv(z)e−|ℜz|
                      • hankel1: Hankel function of the first kind, 𝐻(1)𝑣(𝑧)Hv(1)(z)
                      • hankel1e: Exponentially scaled Hankel function of the first kind, 𝐻(1)𝑣(𝑧)𝑒−𝑖𝑧Hv(1)(z)e−iz
                      • hankel2: Hankel function of the second kind, 𝐻(2)𝑣(𝑧)Hv(2)(z)
                      • hankel2e: Exponentially scaled Hankel function of the second kind, 𝐻(2)𝑣(𝑧)𝑒𝑖𝑧Hv(2)(z)eiz
                      • lmbda: Compute sequence of lambda functions with arbitrary order 𝑣v and their derivatives
                    • Zeros of Bessel Functions
                      • jnjnp_zeros: Compute nt (<=1200) zeros of the Bessel functions 𝐽𝑛Jn and 𝐽′𝑛Jn′ and arange them in order of their magnitudes
                      • jnyn_zeros: Compute nt zeros of the Bessel functions 𝐽𝑛(𝑥)Jn(x), 𝐽′𝑛(𝑥)Jn′(x), 𝑌𝑛(𝑥)Yn(x), and 𝑌′𝑛(𝑥)Yn′(x), respectively
                      • jn_zeros: Compute nt zeros of the Bessel function 𝐽𝑛(𝑥)Jn(x)
                      • jnp_zeros: Compute nt zeros of the Bessel function 𝐽′𝑛(𝑥)Jn′(x)
                      • yn_zeros: Compute nt zeros of the Bessel function 𝑌𝑛(𝑥)Yn(x)
                      • ynp_zeros: Compute nt zeros of the Bessel function 𝑌′𝑛(𝑥)Yn′(x)
                      • y0_zeros: Returns nt (complex or real) zeros of 𝑌0(𝑧)Y0(z), 𝑧0z0, and the value of 𝑌′0(𝑧0)=−𝑌1(𝑧0)Y0′(z0)=−Y1(z0) at each zero
                      • y1_zeros: Returns nt (complex or real) zeros of 𝑌1(𝑧)Y1(z), 𝑧1z1, and the value of 𝑌′1(𝑧1)=𝑌0(𝑧1)Y1′(z1)=Y0(z1) at each zero
                      • y1p_zeros: Returns nt (complex or real) zeros of 𝑌′1(𝑧)Y1′(z), 𝑧′1z1′, and the value of 𝑌1(𝑧′1)Y1(z1′) at each zero
                    • Faster versions of common Bessel Functions
                      • j0: Bessel function the first kind of order 0, 𝐽0(𝑥)J0(x)
                      • j1: Bessel function of the first kind of order 1, 𝐽1(𝑥)J1(x)
                      • y0: Bessel function of the second kind of order 0, 𝑌0(𝑥)Y0(x)
                      • y1: Bessel function of the second kind of order 1, 𝑌1(𝑥)Y1(x)

                      • i1: Modified Bessel function of order 1, 𝐼1(𝑥)I1(x)

                      • iti0k0: Integrals of modified Bessel functions of order 0: ∫𝑥0𝐼0(𝑡)𝑑𝑡∫0xI0(t)dt, ∫𝑥0𝐾0(𝑡)𝑑𝑡∫0xK0(t)dt
                      • it2i0k0: Integrals related to modified Bessel functions of order 0: ∫𝑥0𝐼0(𝑡)−1𝑡𝑑𝑡∫0xI0(t)−1tdt, ∫∞𝑥𝐾0(𝑡)𝑡𝑑𝑡∫x∞K0(t)tdt

            # Customer analysis

            Customer analysis¶

            xxxxxxxxxx
             
            In this exercise, you work for a consulting firm as data analyst. One of your clients asked for help to understand its customer buying behavior. 
            ​
            You dispose of a dataset from its e-commerce website with 13 features : 
            ​
            - order_id : ID if the order
            - order_status : Status of the order
            - order_purchase_timestamp : Timestamp of the purchase
            - order_delivered_customer_date : Timestamp of the delivery to the customer
            - payment_type : Method of payment
            - payment_installments : Number of payments for this purchase (does NOT affect the payment value)
            - payment_value : Total amount of the payment
            - review_score : Score given by the client, ranges from 1 to 5
            - customer_unique_id : ID of the customer who purchased
            - customer_zip_code_prefix : Zip code of the customer
            - customer_city : City of the customer
            - customer_state : State of the customer
            - product_category_name_english : Name of the product category in English
            ​
            With this data, you have to analyze customer behavior with two techniques:
            ​
            - Customer segmentation with RFM
            - Cohort analysis from Sept 2016 to October 2018.
            ​
            At the end, you have to present your analysis with actionable insights to improve the customer relationship of your client.

            In this exercise, you work for a consulting firm as data analyst. One of your clients asked for help to understand its customer buying behavior.

            You dispose of a dataset from its e-commerce website with 13 features :

            • order_id : ID if the order
            • order_status : Status of the order
            • order_purchase_timestamp : Timestamp of the purchase
            • order_delivered_customer_date : Timestamp of the delivery to the customer
            • payment_type : Method of payment
            • payment_installments : Number of payments for this purchase (does NOT affect the payment value)
            • payment_value : Total amount of the payment
            • review_score : Score given by the client, ranges from 1 to 5
            • customer_unique_id : ID of the customer who purchased
            • customer_zip_code_prefix : Zip code of the customer
            • customer_city : City of the customer
            • customer_state : State of the customer
            • product_category_name_english : Name of the product category in English

            With this data, you have to analyze customer behavior with two techniques:

            • Customer segmentation with RFM
            • Cohort analysis from Sept 2016 to October 2018.

            At the end, you have to present your analysis with actionable insights to improve the customer relationship of your client.

            # Understanding RFM Segmentation

            Understanding RFM Segmentation¶

            xxxxxxxxxx
             
            ❓ What are the 3 metrics used in an RFM Segmentation? (hint : What does RFM stand for?)

            ❓ What are the 3 metrics used in an RFM Segmentation? (hint : What does RFM stand for?) 

            xxxxxxxxxx
             
            **RFM stands for Recency, Frequency, and Monetary value**

            RFM stands for Recency, Frequency, and Monetary value

            xxxxxxxxxx
             
            ❓ Can you summarize what each metric measures in one sentence?

            ❓ Can you summarize what each metric measures in one sentence?

            xxxxxxxxxx
             
            **Method of analyzing the quality of a customer according to three criteria :**  
            ​
            **Recency: date of the last purchase or time elapsed since.(The most the recent purchases the better score will be)   
            Frequency: average frequency of purchases over the period considered.(The more frequent purchase the better score will be)  
            Value: amount of purchases made by this customer over the period studied.(The more they spend the better score will be)**

            Method of analyzing the quality of a customer according to three criteria :

            Recency: date of the last purchase or time elapsed since.(The most the recent purchases the better score will be)
            Frequency: average frequency of purchases over the period considered.(The more frequent purchase the better score will be)
            Value: amount of purchases made by this customer over the period studied.(The more they spend the better score will be)

            Entrée [96]:
             
            # Functions to create R, F, M segments
            def Rscoring(x,p,d):
                if x <= d[p][0.25]:
                    return 1
                elif x <= d[p][0.50]:
                    return 2
                elif x <= d[p][0.75]:
                    return 3
                else:
                    return 4
            ​
            def FnMcoring(x,p,d):
                if x <= d[p][0.25]:
                    return 4
                elif x <= d[p][0.50]:
                    return 3
                elif x <= d[p][0.75]:
                    return 2
                else:
                    return 1
            . . .
            Entrée [97]:
             
            RFMScores['R'] = RFMScores['Recency'].apply(Rscoring, args=('Recency',quantiles,))
            RFMScores['F'] = RFMScores['Frequency'].apply(Rscoring, args=('Frequency',quantiles,))
            RFMScores['M'] = RFMScores['Monetary'].apply(Rscoring, args=('Monetary',quantiles,))

            Here is the code for the analysis of customers who have bought more than once :

            Entrée [ ]:
            xxxxxxxxxx
             
            #start from your df created doing the RFM segmentation
            df_c = df[['customer_unique_id', 'order_id',
                       'order_purchase_timestamp']].drop_duplicates()
            ​
            df_c['order_month'] = df_c['order_purchase_timestamp'].dt.to_period('M')
            ​
            df_more = pd.DataFrame(df_c.groupby('customer_unique_id').size()[
                                   df_c.groupby('customer_unique_id').size() > 1])
            ​
            df_c = df_c.merge(df_more, how='left', on='customer_unique_id').rename(
                columns={0: 'na'})
            ​
            df_c = df_c[df_c['na'].notna()]
            df_c['cohort'] = df_c.groupby('customer_unique_id')['order_purchase_timestamp'] \
                .transform('min') \
                .dt.to_period('M')
            ​
            df_cohort = df_c.groupby(['cohort', 'order_month']) \
                .agg(n_customers=('customer_unique_id', 'nunique')) \
                .reset_index(drop=False)
            df_cohort['period_number'] = (
                df_cohort.order_month - df_cohort.cohort).apply(attrgetter('n'))
            cohort_pivot = df_cohort.pivot_table(index='cohort',
                                                 columns='period_number',
                                                 values='n_customers')
            cohort_size = cohort_pivot.iloc[:, 0]
            retention_matrix = cohort_pivot.divide(cohort_size, axis=0)
            ​
            with sns.axes_style("white"):
                fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(12, 8), sharey=True, gridspec_kw={
                                       'width_ratios': [1, 11]})
            ​
                # retention matrix
                sns.heatmap(retention_matrix,
                            mask=retention_matrix.isnull(),
                            annot=True,
                            fmt='.0%',
                            cmap='RdYlGn',
                            ax=ax[1])
                ax[1].set_title('Monthly Cohorts: User Retention', fontsize=16)
                ax[1].set(xlabel='# of periods',
                          ylabel='')
            ​
                # cohort size
                cohort_size_df = pd.DataFrame(cohort_size).rename(
                    columns={0: 'cohort_size'})
                white_cmap = mcolors.ListedColormap(['white'])
                sns.heatmap(cohort_size_df,
                            annot=True,
                            cbar=False,
                            fmt='g',
                            cmap=white_cmap,

            Signature:
pd.qcut(
    x,
    q,
    labels=None,
    retbins: bool = False,
    precision: int = 3,
    duplicates: str = 'raise',
)
Docstring:
Quantile-based discretization function.

Discretize variable into equal-sized buckets based on rank or based
on sample quantiles. For example 1000 values for 10 quantiles would
produce a Categorical object indicating quantile membership for each data point.

Parameters
----------
x : 1d ndarray or Series
q : int or list-like of float
    Number of quantiles. 10 for deciles, 4 for quartiles, etc. Alternately
    array of quantiles, e.g. [0, .25, .5, .75, 1.] for quartiles.
labels : array or False, default None
    Used as labels for the resulting bins. Must be of the same length as
    the resulting bins. If False, return only integer indicators of the
    bins. If True, raises an error.
retbins : bool, optional
    Whether to return the (bins, labels) or not. Can be useful if bins
    is given as a scalar.
precision : int, optional
    The precision at which to store and display the bins labels.
duplicates : {default 'raise', 'drop'}, optional
    If bin edges are not unique, raise ValueError or drop non-uniques.

Returns
-------
out : Categorical or Series or array of integers if labels is False
    The return type (Categorical or Series) depends on the input: a Series
    of type category if input is a Series else Categorical. Bins are
    represented as categories when categorical data is returned.
bins : ndarray of floats
    Returned only if `retbins` is True.

Notes
-----
Out of bounds values will be NA in the resulting Categorical object

Examples
--------
>>> pd.qcut(range(5), 4)
... # doctest: +ELLIPSIS
[(-0.001, 1.0], (-0.001, 1.0], (1.0, 2.0], (2.0, 3.0], (3.0, 4.0]]
Categories (4, interval[float64]): [(-0.001, 1.0] < (1.0, 2.0] ...

>>> pd.qcut(range(5), 3, labels=["good", "medium", "bad"])
... # doctest: +SKIP
[good, good, medium, bad, bad]
Categories (3, object): [good < medium < bad]

>>> pd.qcut(range(5), 4, labels=False)
array([0, 0, 1, 2, 3])
File:      c:\users\simplon\anaconda3\lib\site-packages\pandas\core\reshape\tile.py
